user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_remove_:
```c
static int lfs_remove_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path) {
    // deorphan if we haven't yet, needed at most once after poweron
    int err = lfs_fs_forceconsistency(lfs);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0 || lfs_tag_id(tag) == 0x3ff) {
        return (tag < 0) ? (int)tag : LFS_ERR_INVAL;
    }

    struct lfs_mlist dir;
    dir.next = lfs->mlist;
    if (lfs_tag_type3(tag) == LFS_TYPE_DIR) {
        // must be empty before removal
        lfs_block_t pair[2];
        lfs_stag_t res = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKTAG(0x700, 0x3ff, 0),
                LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_STRUCT, lfs_tag_id(tag), 8), pair);
        if (res < 0) {
            return (int)res;
        }
        lfs_pair_fromle32(pair);

        err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir.m, pair);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        if (dir.m.count > 0 || dir.m.split) {
            return LFS_ERR_NOTEMPTY;
        }

        // mark fs as orphaned
        err = lfs_fs_preporphans(lfs, +1);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        // I know it's crazy but yes, dir can be changed by our parent's
        // commit (if predecessor is child)
        dir.type = 0;
        dir.id = 0;
        lfs->mlist = &dir;
    }

    // delete the entry
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_DELETE, lfs_tag_id(tag), 0), NULL}));
    if (err) {
        lfs->mlist = dir.next;
        return err;
    }

    lfs->mlist = dir.next;
    if (lfs_gstate_hasorphans(&lfs->gstate)) {
        LFS_ASSERT(lfs_tag_type3(tag) == LFS_TYPE_DIR);

        // fix orphan
        err = lfs_fs_preporphans(lfs, -1);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        err = lfs_fs_pred(lfs, dir.m.pair, &cwd);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        err = lfs_dir_drop(lfs, &cwd, &dir.m);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_remove_:
#define LFS_MKATTRS(__VA_ARGS__) (structlfs_mattr[]){__VA_ARGS__},sizeof((structlfs_mattr[]){__VA_ARGS__})/sizeof(structlfs_mattr)
...
#define LFS_MKTAG(type, id, size) (((lfs_tag_t)(type)<<20)|((lfs_tag_t)(id)<<10)|(lfs_tag_t)(size))
...
static int lfs_dir_commit(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_mdir_t *dir,
        const struct lfs_mattr *attrs, int attrcount) {
    int orphans = lfs_dir_orphaningcommit(lfs, dir, attrs, attrcount);
    if (orphans < 0) {
        return orphans;
    }

    if (orphans) {
        // make sure we've removed all orphans, this is a noop if there
        // are none, but if we had nested blocks failures we may have
        // created some
        int err = lfs_fs_deorphan(lfs, false);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static inline uint16_t lfs_tag_id(lfs_tag_t tag) {
    return (tag & 0x000ffc00) >> 10;
}
...
static inline uint16_t lfs_tag_type3(lfs_tag_t tag) {
    return (tag & 0x7ff00000) >> 20;
}
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    }
...
typedef struct lfs_mdir {
    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    uint32_t rev;
    lfs_off_t off;
    uint32_t etag;
    uint16_t count;
    bool erased;
    bool split;
    lfs_block_t tail[2];
} lfs_mdir_t
...
typedef int32_t lfs_stag_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_block_t
...
static inline void lfs_pair_fromle32(lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    pair[0] = lfs_fromle32(pair[0]);
    pair[1] = lfs_fromle32(pair[1]);
}
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. In particular:
- There are no gcc/clang-specific keywords or tokens such as __attribute__, __extension__, __builtin_*, __asm__, __label__, __typeof__, or __volatile__ used.
- There are no GNU statement-expressions ({ ... }) or nested functions (a GCC extension).
- The macro LFS_MKATTRS uses a compound literal (struct lfs_mattr[]){ ... }, which is a standard C99 feature (not a compiler extension). Its usage in the call site (LFS_MKATTRS({ ... })) is a macro/initializer idiom that expands to compound literal expressions; this is standard-conforming, not an extension.
- Use of inline functions (static inline), fixed-width integer types (int32_t, uint32_t), bool/false, and single-line comments (//) are all standard C (C99 or later), not compiler extensions.
- Bitwise operations, shifts, casts and other language constructs used are standard C.

Given the absence of compiler-specific constructs in the snippet and its related definitions, there are no fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (prohibition of language extensions). If you have other files or build-specific macros (e.g. compiler-specific attributes or pragmas) not shown here, provide them so I can re-evaluate.
